docs.lead_paragraph: LAST year, a crate containing a plaster bust of James Danforth Quayle was delivered to the doorstep of a squat, dusty building in Long Island City. A bust of the former vice president, lifelike down to the dimple in his tie, just sitting there, in a box. In Long Island City. Some among us might have seen a party prop in such a delivery. Imagine, a bust of that boyish conservative Republican from Indiana, remembered mostly for criticizing a sitcom single mother named Murphy Brown and for demonstrating how one misspelling can dog you all your days.
docs.abstract: Dan Barry column reports on Daniel Sinclair, sculptor who will finish bust of former Vice Pres Dan Quayle for Capitol in Washington; bust was started 10 years ago by late Frederick Hart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Evelyn Trout, a pioneering aviator who flew in the first Powder Puff Derby and held many records, including becoming the first woman to fly all night, died on Jan. 24 in San Diego. She was 97. Known as Bobbi for her bob hairstyle, she had an international pilot's license signed by Orville Wright in 1929 that was carried into space in 1995 by Eileen Collins, the first woman to be the pilot of an American spacecraft.
docs.abstract: Evelyn Trout, pioneering aviator who set many records for endurance and altitude, dies at age 97; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THEY are still not amused in Yaphank by a cartoon published in The New Yorker 20 years ago that comically suggested that this hamlet in the Town of Brookhaven with the hayseed name wasn't worth a second look. The cartoon showed an off-ramp sign that advised: ''Exit 66, Yaphank. If You Have Already Been to Yaphank, Disregard This Exit.''
docs.abstract: Article on continuing debate among residents of Yaphank, Long Island, who have decided, in 245 to 236 vote, not to incorporate into village; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Stretched across Bryant McKinnie's giant torso was a tight T-shirt bearing a cartoon and a slogan. He is the Miami Hurricanes' left offensive tackle, a deluxe run and pass blocker at 6-feet-9 and 335 pounds. The illustration showed a road-paving machine. ''O-line steam-rolling you,'' the message on the T-shirt declared. This is pretty much what McKinnie and his teammates did Saturday night in a 33-7 victory over Penn State in the season opener for both teams in State College, Pa. Is second-ranked Miami really this good? Are the Nittany Lions really this bad? Perhaps Miami will be even better on Saturday when it plays at home against Rutgers in a Big East opener that will match rookie coaches.
docs.abstract: Miami Hurricanes football is looking formidable again this season, following Miami's 33-7 season-opening victory over Penn State (M)

headline.main: Miami Has That Formidable Look Once Again

docs.lead_paragraph: Strolling around the serene square of this Basque town not far north of Bilbao, it is hard to imagine the scene as it was some 60 years ago, when an indelible atrocity took place here on the eve of World War II. Only a few outward marks of physical devastation are still visible, but the human damage remains embedded in people's minds. If you tap the memories of the survivors of the German bombing during the Spanish Civil War, and listen to local officials and historians who are trying to turn one of the symbols of fascist militarism into a place of peace and reconciliation, the day is always April 26, 1937. That Monday -- a crowded market day when farmers from nearby villages came to Guernica to sell and exchange livestock and produce -- was deliberately chosen by the Luftwaffe to inflict the greatest number of casualties.
docs.abstract: Herbert Mitgang column on Guernica, Spain, whose destruction in 1937 German bombing attack during Spanish Civil War inspired Pablo Picasso painting; cites local efforts to turn town into place of peace and reconciliation; photo (M)

headline.main: In Guernica, Determination to 'Forgive, but Never Forget'

docs.lead_paragraph: An Actor Makes a Splash John Lithgow has appeared before the American public in guises ranging from a football player turned transsexual (the film ''The World According to Garp'') to a space alien masquerading as a physics professor (the sitcom ''Third Rock From the Sun''). But tomorrow he will play what may be his most surprising role: children's entertainer. ''I'm surprised myself,'' Mr. Lithgow said. ''I haven't quite mastered it yet. It's in-service training. I'm learning to sing in front of an orchestra with 2,800 screaming children.'' In the past, Mr. Lithgow has usually elicited screams only when playing a psychopath. Things will be far less scary tomorrow at Carnegie Hall, where he will present a family concert based on his 1999 album, ''Singin' in the Bathtub,'' released by Sony Wonder.
docs.abstract: Family Fare column of upcoming events of interest to families in New York; photo (S)
